blog.name: winterfellchild
blog.title: The pack survives
blog.description:
"She (Daenerys) has the power to destroy, she can wipe out entire cities, and we
certainly see that in ‘Fire and Blood.’ We see the dragons wiping out 
entire armies, wiping out towns and cities, destroying them, but that 
doesn’t necessarily enable you to rule — it just enables you to destroy." GRRM

tags: that interview was about Varys joining Dænerys team
the petty part of me loves that he ended it with some tea about Sansa
about what an interesting character she really is
summary: April 19, 2015, Conleth Hill Talks Varys' Allegiance - Making Game of Thrones   Love Conleth too, he chose a direwolf AND he...
caption:
April 19, 2015, Conleth Hill Talks Varys’ Allegiance - Making Game of Thrones

Love Conleth too, he chose a direwolf AND he figured out Sansa’s strength since 2015. 

Bonus points because that was an interview about his character storyline in season 5 ( when Varys joined Dænerys team) and he still talked about how great Sansa would be on the IT, an amazing politician and diplomat… and he was right.

summary: Sansa’s Mercy
title: Sansa’s Mercy
body:
The infamous “undermining” scene between Jon and Sansa is about more than simply their dynamic as co-rulers. It is about more than who was right or wrong in their approach of each other. It is about more than foreshadowing the success or failure of Jon and Sansa’s relationship, romantic or otherwise.

This scene is about mercy and Sansa’s complicated journey with it throughout this story. Jon’s decision to grant mercy to the Umbers and Karstarks helps Sansa start to remember her own mercy again, a core part of her true self. 

When Sansa disagrees with Jon over how to deal with the families that fought against them, she is working from a place of vigilance. Sansa knows that being too merciful can result in more betrayal. Jon knows that mercy can lead to greater loyalty. Ned knew that sometimes mercy is just simply the right thing to do. All of these perspectives are simultaneously correct and limited on their own.

The Starks are at their best when they work as a team. The wolves are a pack. They need each other, so that their individual strengths can balance out each other’s individual weaknesses. When Arya returns and wants to behead men for insulting the king, Sansa points out that this isn’t the right approach. She is doing for Arya what Jon did for her, demonstrating mercy.

The concept of mercy is such an important aspect of who Sansa is as a character. She embodies mercy at such a young age, in a way that is unique to her among the Stark children and most others within this world. 

Mercy is at the center of many of Sansa’s scenes. She begs Cersei not to kill Lady. She begs for mercy to spare her father’s life. Neither works.

“I don’t want to marry you,” Sansa wailed. “You chopped off my father’s head!”

“He was a traitor. I never promised to spare him, only that I’d be merciful, and I was. If he hadn’t been your father, I would have had him torn or flayed, but I gave him a clean death.”

Sansa stared at him, seeing him for the first time. 

- AGOT, Sansa VI

She is told by Joffrey that killing Ned quickly was mercy, which she later uses to manipulate him into not killing Ser Dontos. 

This is an important lesson that she needs to learn, to see people for who they really are. It helps her to survive and start to influence those around her. But Sansa knows her father’s death was no mercy.

“Joffrey did that. He cut my father’s head off and he said that was mercy.”

Sansa is subjected to brutality after brutality, robbing her of her idealism, and as a result this causes her to doubt her own merciful nature. She starts to believe that mercy isn’t real, and that she must rid herself of these foolish beliefs or she will be killed just like her father.

When Sansa gets back to Winterfell after the Battle of the Bastards, she is a changed person. All of the Starks are. They have suffered, and fought, and learned lessons along the way. They each return home with the added baggage and benefits of time. But deep down, the core of who they are will ultimately be the source of their greatest strengths, if they can hold onto it.

Quite understandably, Sansa is hyper-vigilant after all she’s been through. She finds it difficult to trust and has learned the harsh realities of needing to be ruthlessness. In her adaptive study of her captors she has learned to see, and often expect, the worst in people. These are valuable and necessary skills of leadership in the climate within which she lives. These are the aspect that Ned Stark lacked when he went South, and she knows that.

Still, Sansa is home. 

She is a Stark of Winterfell, and despite the cruelties that threaten the safety of her home and family, the “madness of mercy” that her father passed onto her will be her greatest power in the end. With all of the strength and political savvy Sansa has gained throughout her journey, she still needs to reawaken the core truth of who she is. She needs to reacquaint herself with the parts of her that she first had to hide, and then tried to rid herself of, believing that they were her weaknesses. The greatest of these being mercy.

Sansa has gained so much awareness of the world around her and through that has learned to play the game as well as the enemies that taught her. This has and will help her defeat those enemies. 

But that is only a small part of her story.

Sansa is ultimately meant to rule, to lead. Whether it is as the Queen of the Seven Kingdoms, the Wardeness of the North, the Lady of Winterfell, or simply the matriarch of her own family, this is Sansa’s destiny. She embodies the Mother and the Mother is, above all, merciful. 

When Ser Dontos is being tortured in front of her, most of the people standing around watching find it amusing but Sansa’s finds it intolerable. When she yells, “you can’t,” she is speaking directly to the men forcing the wine down his throat, not Joffrey, almost as if he weren’t there.

It isn’t a plea for Joffrey to stop, it is a declaration of mercy as though the Mother were being channelled through her. It’s as if we are getting a glimpse of Sansa’s future self, a ruling queen giving a royal command.

From the beginning, Sansa knew what she was - a lady at three - and she knew what kind of ruler she wanted to be.  

“I will remember, Your Grace,“ said Sansa, though she had always heard that love was a surer route to the people’s loyalty than fear. If I am ever a queen, I’ll make them love me.” 

- ACOK, Sansa VI

Showing mercy is a huge part of how this will come to be. This is a major part of her true self and her relationship with Jon and the rest of her family will aid her in remembering that. 

“She sang for mercy, for the living and the dead alike, for Bran and Rickon and Robb, for her sister Arya and her bastard brother Jon Snow, away off on the Wall. She sang for her mother and her father, for her grandfather Lord Hoster and her uncle Edmure Tully, for her friend Jeyne Poole, for old drunken King Robert, for Septa Mordane and Ser Dontos and Jory Cassel and Maester Luwin, for all the brave knights and soldiers who would die today, and for the children and the wives who would mourn them, and finally, toward the end, she even sang for Tyrion the Imp and for the Hound. He is no true knight but he saved me all the same, she told the Mother. Save him if you can, and gentle the rage inside him.” 

- ACOK, Sansa V

summary: Traditional femininity is not innately inferior. It has its own kind of strength and its own kind of power, and Sansa Stark...
caption:
Traditional femininity is not innately inferior. It has its own kind of strength and its own kind of power, and Sansa Stark demonstrates that better than any other character I’ve encountered. She is not fierce or rebellious. She is not ruthless or brutal. But she is strong. She is a survivor. And that should not be dismissed.

—In Defense of Sansa Stark

summary: Sansa (5'9") isn't just taller than Dany (5'2"), she's also taller than Cersei    (5'5") now. If the kidnapping plot happens,...
question: Sansa (5'9") isn't just taller than Dany (5'2"), she's also taller than Cersei    (5'5") now. If the kidnapping plot happens, I'm sure the directors are going to use the height difference again except this time it will be the Sansa being physically and morally 'taller' than the woman who abused her as a child. The height difference can also play into the YMBQ prophecy with Sansa winning one over Cersei in every way including height.
answer: Oh I like that idea nonny ! That’s really interesting !

summary: Daenerys stans are really out there going on about how we hate her because we want Sansa to get what Daenerys has when they are...

tags: they're in our shoes for two seconds and they get that whiny about it...lmao
arya stans could never survive what we survived
summary: People constantly complain about how the writers favor Sansa over every other character as if didn’t remove Sandor’s verbal,...
body: People constantly complain about how the writers favor Sansa over every other character as if didn’t remove Sandor’s verbal, physical and sexual abuse of Sansa in order for him to seem like more of a good guy, as if they didn’t remove Tyrion’s molestation and sexual attraction to Sansa in order to make his character as ideal as possible, as if they didn’t turn Margaery manipulating Sansa into her being a true friend to make her less flawed, as if they didn’t remove the more explicit sections of Littlefinger’s grooming of Sansa because that would make him less of a cool villain and more of a creepy villain, as if they didn’t make Sansa going back to Winterfell more about Ramsey being a terrible villain than about her because they liked him that much, and as if they didn’t make her storyline about retaking Winterfell from the family that abused her more about their favorite action boy. The writers have at every step of the way prioritized their favorite male (and Margaery) characters over Sansa, so could we please stop pretending that just because they’re doing the same thing to Arya (for like two episodes in a story-line that doesn’t even benefit Sansa…like at all) that they’ve did to Sansa every single damn season, that Sansa is somehow pampered by the writers.

reblog.comment: People constantly complain about how the writers favor Sansa over every other character as if didn’t remove Sandor’s verbal, physical and sexual abuse of Sansa in order for him to seem like more of a good guy, as if they didn’t remove Tyrion’s molestation and sexual attraction to Sansa in order to make his character as ideal as possible, as if they didn’t turn Margaery manipulating Sansa into her being a true friend to make her less flawed, as if they didn’t remove the more explicit sections of Littlefinger’s grooming of Sansa because that would make him less of a cool villain and more of a creepy villain, as if they didn’t make Sansa going back to Winterfell more about Ramsey being a terrible villain than about her because they liked him that much, and as if they didn’t make her storyline about retaking Winterfell from the family that abused her more about their favorite action boy. The writers have at every step of the way prioritized their favorite male (and Margaery) characters over Sansa, so could we please stop pretending that just because they’re doing the same thing to Arya (for like two episodes in a story-line that doesn’t even benefit Sansa…like at all) that they’ve did to Sansa every single damn season, that Sansa is somehow pampered by the writers.

trail.content_raw: People constantly complain about how the writers favor Sansa over every other character as if didn’t remove Sandor’s verbal, physical and sexual abuse of Sansa in order for him to seem like more of a good guy, as if they didn’t remove Tyrion’s molestation and sexual attraction to Sansa in order to make his character as ideal as possible, as if they didn’t turn Margaery manipulating Sansa into her being a true friend to make her less flawed, as if they didn’t remove the more explicit sections of Littlefinger’s grooming of Sansa because that would make him less of a cool villain and more of a creepy villain, as if they didn’t make Sansa going back to Winterfell more about Ramsey being a terrible villain than about her because they liked him that much, and as if they didn’t make her storyline about retaking Winterfell from the family that abused her more about their favorite action boy. The writers have at every step of the way prioritized their favorite male (and Margaery) characters over Sansa, so could we please stop pretending that just because they’re doing the same thing to Arya (for like two episodes in a story-line that doesn’t even benefit Sansa…like at all) that they’ve did to Sansa every single damn season, that Sansa is somehow pampered by the writers.

The writers have at every step of the way prioritized their favorite male (and Margaery) characters over Sansa, so could we please stop pretending that just because they’re doing the same thing to Arya (for like two episodes in a story-line that doesn’t even benefit Sansa…like at all) that they’ve did to Sansa every single damn season, that Sansa is somehow pampered by the writers.

summary: Ok so they emphasize Jon being different from the other Starks who’ve died in the South yet Sansa already made it home, gained...
body:
Ok so they emphasize Jon being different from the other Starks who’ve died in the South yet Sansa already made it home, gained allies, helped unseat the Boltons, and is Lady of Winterfell.

Might be she knows a thing or two about that already.

summary: The same people who degraded Sansa because she told Littlefinger that King’s Landing was her home due to the fact that she...
body: The same people who degraded Sansa because she told Littlefinger that King’s Landing was her home due to the fact that she didn’t trust him enough to accept his proposal to bring her home (for fear of being caught in a trap) and who criticized her for choosing the Tyrells plan to wed her to Loras instead of his are the same people who call her stupid for “trusting” Littlefinger and his plan in dealing with the Boltons. So essentially, they hate on her for doing something, all while telling her to do the exact opposite, and when she does just that, she just receives more criticism. Make it make sense. Make it make sense.

reblog.comment: The same people who degraded Sansa because she told Littlefinger that King’s Landing was her home due to the fact that she didn’t trust him enough to accept his proposal to bring her home (for fear of being caught in a trap) and who criticized her for choosing the Tyrells plan to wed her to Loras instead of his are the same people who call her stupid for “trusting” Littlefinger and his plan in dealing with the Boltons. So essentially, they hate on her for doing something, all while telling her to do the exact opposite, and when she does just that, she just receives more criticism. Make it make sense. Make it make sense.

So essentially, they hate on her for doing something, all while telling her to do the exact opposite, and when she does just that, she just receives more criticism. Make it make sense. Make it make sense.

blog.name: kallypsowrites
blog.title: Kallypso Thoughts
blog.description: Welcome to the messy mind of an author, English teacher and maybe an adult. I post writing stuff sometimes. Mostly I reblog memes

summary: So I’m a major stan of the Stark sisters. Arya and Sansa are my number two and three favorite characters in the series. But I...
body:
So I’m a major stan of the Stark sisters. Arya and Sansa are my number two and three favorite characters in the series. But I primarily write with Arya in my fanfiction because I personally understand and relate to her character more. So of course, my primary readers are other Arya stans, but not necessarily Sansa stans. Some of them even heavily dislike Sansa. But Sansa is still always a part of the fics in some form, and naturally I put just as much effort into writing her in character because she is my baby.

And let me tell you, everytime I get a review that says something to the effect of “I don’t usually like Sansa but you made me like Sansa” my heart grows three sizes. Having stans of a character say they like how I write their fave is one thing. Having people who usually dislike or even hate a character say they like the character in my fic is the best feeling in the world!
